chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Beginning with SpecTcl 5.5, SpecTcl almost fully encapsulates all of its commands with a REST interface. This allows applications external to SpecTcl to fully control it. The intent is to allow SpecTcl to run headless in the background, persistenty under the NSCLDAQ experiment manager. This supports a persistent analysis engine indpenedeent of the users logged in to run the experiment.
The SpecTcl REST support packages are divided into four packages:

listitem.para: SpecTclRESTClient is a low level client package that provides TCL script access to all REST interfaces.
SpecTclRESTCommands simulates SpecTcl commands for REST clients. This package aids in porting existing SpecTcl user interface scripts to run as REST clients.

SpecTclRESTLookup can only be used in the context of a running experiment. It assumes SpecTcl is running under the NSCLDAQ Manager as a service advertised with the NSCLDAQ port manager and, if possible, provides a client object (as defined in SpecTclRESTClient).

SpecTclRESTService can be used in SpecTclInit.tcl for SpecTcl run under the NSCLDAQ manager to register a servicename for the REST server and communicate the allocated port to the REST server startup.

chapter.para: The remainder of this document both describes and provides reference information for these packages.

chapter.title: SpecTclRESTClient package
chapter.para: This package provides a simple REST client for SpecTcl once it's service port is known.

listitem.para: Include the package in your program using package require, note that you may need to extend the package search path to include the package library for the version of SpecTcl you are using.
Instantiate a SpecTclRestClient object. To do this you must know the host in which SpecTcl is running and the port on which its REST server is listening for connections.

Call methods in the instantiated SpecTclRestClient object to perform REST operations. Note that each method will connect to the server, make a request, obtain the results and close the connection. Peristent sockets are not used.

chapter.para: The program below shows how to obtain and output a list of all of the spectrum names for spectra defined in the server SpecTcl.

example.title: Sample SpecTcl REST client using SpecTclRESTClient
example.programlisting:
package require SpecTclRESTClient
set port 8080 set host genesis.nscl.msu.edu
SpecTclRestClient c -host $host -port $port set spectraInfo [c spectrumList] foreach spectrum $spectraInfo { puts [dict get $spectrum name] } c destroy

callout.para: This includes the code for the SpecTclRESTClient library package in the script. It may be necessary to extend the TCL Library search path to include the TclLibs directory within the SpecTcl installation you are using.

This can be done within the script by using lappend to add that directory to the auto_path gloal variable or by defining the TCLLIBPATH environment variable to be a space separated list of library directories to add to the search path.
Note that the environment variable method can be done on the command line e.g. TCLLIBPATH=/usr/opt/spectcl/5.5-000 tclsh defines the environment variable only for that run of the tclsh command.
For the purposes of this simple test program, we define the host in which the SpecTcl we want to talk to is in and the port on which its REST server is listening as hard coded variable values.

This constructs a new instance of a SpecTclRestClient object. The first parameter is the object name or the special string %AUTO% to get a unique name installed. The command returns the name of the new command ensemble in any event.

The -host option allows you to provide a host on which the server (SpecTcl) is running and -port provides the port to which the connection will be made. This must be the port on which SpecTcl is listening.

The object constructed above becomes a new command ensemble. Methods are invoked via subcommands. This line uses the spectrumList method to ask the client object to interact with SpecTcl on the configured -host and -port to get a list of all spectra and their properties. Essentially, this does a remote execution of spectrum -list in SpecTcl and returns information from that command.
The information returned by this method is a list of dicts, one for each spectrum. Each dict has the following keys:

listitem.para: Name of the spectrum.
SpecTcl Spectrum type code.
List of parameter needed by the spectrum.
List of axis definitions (this is a list of dicts with the keys low, high and bins).
Data type for each channel. This can be one of long, word or byte.

callout.para: This foreach loop iterates over the list of dicts, fetches the name from each and outputs it to stdout.

Destroys the client object we created. This releases any resources consumed by that object. In a simple program like this, when the next action is to exit the script, it's not actually necessary to destroy the object. In a more complex script, it's always a good idea to dispose of resources you no longer need.

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This package provides low level client access to the SpecTcl REST server available in SpecTcl 5.5 and later. Instantiating an object creates a new command ensemble. Subcommands perform specific REST transactions.

refsect1.title: OPTIONS
refsect1.para: The following two options are used to configure the connections the instantiated client objects use. Since connections are made for every transaction, by nature, these options are dynamic.

listitem.para: The DNS hostname or IP address of the system that will be connected to for REST transactions
The port number that will be conneted to for REST transactions. A SpecTcl REST server must be listening for connections on that port in the system specified by -host.

refsect1.title: METHODS
refsect1.para: Instantiated objects are command ensembles. Each subcommand of the ensemble can be thought of as an object method. Two standard methods: configure and cget allow users of the object to configure the connection parameters of the object. Since each method that performs a REST operation connects with the server each operation, the configuration is fully dynamic.
The methods supported by the client objects are divided into categories which will be described in different subsections.

refsect2.title: Conditions and gates
refsect2.para: These methods create and manipulate gates and their application as conditions on spectra.

listitem.para: Applies a single gate, specified by gatename to all of the spectra named in the Tcl list of spectrum names in spectra

Produces a list of gate applications. If pattern is provided, it is a pattern against which spectrum names are matched. The pattern can include glob (filesystem type) wildcard characters such as * and ?.
The returned value is a list of dicts. Each dict has the keys spectrum, the name of a spectrumand gate, the name of the gate applied to that spectrum.
Removes all gates from the spectra named in the list spectra, replacing the applied gates with a T gate.

refsect2.title: Data Source and Analysis Control
refsect2.para: These methods control the data source that SpecTcl analyzes data from as well as when analysis occurs.

listitem.para: Attaches a new data source to SpecTcl. If an existing source is attached, any analysis underway from it is stopped and the data source is detached.
The sourceType determines the type of data source and the meaning of the sourceSpec parameter. Legal values are either pipe or file.

For pipe data sources, sourceSpec is a command string that provides data to its stdout, which is on the other end of a pipe SpecTcl reads. For file the data source is a file and the sourceSpec is the name of the event file. Note the filename path is interpreted inthe context of SpecTcl's Tcl interpreter.

If supplied, the size parameter supplies the size of the reads that SpecTcl will perform from the data source. format supplies a format parameter. Unless you are analyzing very old data, the default ring format is correct. Other legal values are nscl for the old 8k NSCLDAQ (pre 10.0) buffer format. Or jumbo for big buffered NSCLDAQ 8.0 or earlier data. In either case, the size must be the same as the size of the buffer.
Returns a string that describes what SpecTcl is attached to as a data source.

When attaching a data source in ring buffer format, it's necessary to specify a format version. This is because the payload format of the ringbuffers has evolved with time. Once you have attached a ring data source, you can use this method to specify the format of the ring buffers. The major parameter is the major version number and currently can be 10 for NSCLDAQ10 and 11 currently for NSCLDAQ11 and higher.

The optional minor parameter allows you to specify a minor verson. If not specified, this defaults to 0 which is normally acceptable because data formats are not allowed to change within a major version as a rule.
Starts analyzing data from the current data source.
Stops analyzing data from the current data source.

refsect2.title: Display Memory Control
refsect2.para: SpecTcl maintains an arbitrary set of spectra. Of these, some or all may be stored in a shared memory segment that provides high performance, low latency access to spectrum data by display programs. These methods control which spectra are in display memory and which are local to SpecTcl.

listitem.para: Attempts to bind all defined spectra into the shared display memory. If this fails (due to a shared memory too small to hold them all and their descriptions), an error is raised.

Attempts to bind several spectra to the display shared memory. The spectra parameter is a Tcl list of spectrumnames. If the bind fails, an error is raised. Typically the bind fails because the shared memory region is not large enough to hold all of the additional spectra.

Returns a list that describes which spectra are bound to the display memory. If pattern is supplied, it must match the bound spectrum name to be included inthe output list. If not supplied, the pattern defaults to * which matches all bindings.

The return value is a list of dicts. Each dict describes a binding of a spectrum to shared memory. Each dict has the keys: spectrum which is the name of a spectrum and binding which is the Xamine binding id.
Unbinds the spectra listed by name in names (a list) from display memory. Note that this does not impact the contents of the spectra. The spectrum contents are copied into private SpecTcl memory.
Unbinds a list of spectra by spectrum id from display memory.
Unbinds all spectra from display memory.

refsect2.title: Fitting
refsect2.para: SpecTcl boasts an extensible fitting subsystem with two built in fits (linear and gaussian sitting on a linear background). The methods in this section provide access to that subsystem.

listitem.para: Creates a new fit object named fitname that fits the data in the spectrum spectrumname between the lowChannel and highChannel parameter limits.

The fit type is specified by fitType The built in fits types are linear and gaussian. Other fit types may be implemented and registered by the specific SpecTcl that's running the REST server. Since the fitType parameter is interpreted in that SpecTcl, these fit types become automatically available to REST clients.

Since spectrum data are not, in general, static, they evolve as more data area analyzed, it's reasonable to assume that fit parameters will not be static either. This method recomputes the fit parameters for each fit whose name matches pattern. If pattern is not supplied, it defaults to *, which matches all fits.
See fitList to get the current set of fit parameters.
Deletes the fit named fitname releasing all resources associated with that object.
Produces a list of fit information. The elements of the list must have fit names that match the pattern. If pattern is not provided it defaults to * which matches all fit names.
The result is a list of dicts where each element of the list describes one fit object and has the followiung keys:
Name of the fit.
Name of the spectrum being fit.
Type of fit.
Low channel limit over which the fit is computed.
High channel limit over which the fit is computed.
A dict of fit parameter names and their values. The actual parameter names will vary depending on the fit type.

refsect2.title: Fold methods
refsect2.para: Folds are a technique used in gamma spectroscopy to remove an existing peak from a spectrum as well as uncorrelated peaks. The idea in SpecTcl is to set a gate as a fold on a gamma spectrum. Such spectra increment parameter sets that don't make that gate. Applying the same gate as a condition on the spectrum requires, further, that only parameters that coincide with those in the fold, other than those that satisfy the fold, increment the spectrum.
The following methods provide access to SpecTcl's folding implementation.

listitem.para: Applies the gate gate as a fold to the spectra named by the list spectra.
Returns information about the folds on spectra that match the pattern. If no pattern is supplied, it defaults to * which matches all spectra.

The result is a list of dicts. Each dict describes a spectrum with an applied fold and has the keys: spectrum - name of the spectrum and gate name of the gate that's applied as a fold to that spectrum.
Removes any fold that might be applied to the specrum.

refsect2.title: Accessing spectrum contents
refsect2.para: Several SpecTcl commands allow script to acces spectrum contents. These are documented in this section.

listitem.para: Returns the value of a channel in the spectrum spectrum. xchannel always must be supplied and is either the 1d channel number to be accessed or the x coordinate of the channel if a 2d spectrum. 2d Spectra require an additional ychannel to specify the y coordinate of th channel to be fetched.
On success, the result is an integer value that is the current value of the requested spetrum channel.
Sets the value of the specified channel in spectrum to value. The xchannel and ychannel parameters have the same meaning and requirements as in channelGet
Clears the spectrum named spectrum. By clear we mean that all channels in that spectrum are set to 0.
Zeroes all channels in all spectra.
In addition to channel values, Spectra, maintain over and undeflow counters, indicating when an event would have caused an increment off either end of that spectrum.
This method returns the statistics of spectra whose name match pattern. If pattern is not provided it defaults to * which matches all spectrum names.
The returned value is a list of dicts. The dicts contain the keys:
Name of the spectrum whose statistics are in this dict.
For 1d spectra, this is a single value that represents the number of times an increment would have occured past the left edge of the specturm.

For 2d spectra this is a two element list where the first element is as above and the second element is the number of times an event would have incremented below the bottom edge of the spectrum. Clearly there can be events that incremenbt bothof these counters.
Similarly to undeflows but for events that would increment to the right of the spectrum limits and, for 2d spectra above the top of the spectrum.
Returns the complete contents of the spectrum name. The spectrum contents are returned as a dict with the keys:
The number of X axis (or 1d) overflows since the last time the spectrum was cleared.
Only present for 2d spectra, the number of overflows on the y axis.
The number of X axis (or 1d) undeflows
The number of Y axis (only present for 2d spectra) underflows.

Spectrum channel data. This is a list of dicts, one for each nonzero channel that contain: x, the X channel or 1d channel, Y the Y channel for 2d spectra only and v the value at the specified channel.

refsect2.title: Spectrum Management
refsect2.para: Spectra in SpecTcl are dynamic entities. They can be created at any time, deleted at any time. They can have gates applied to them at any time.
The methods described in this section provide access to SpecTcl commands that manipulate the set of SpecTcl spectra.

listitem.para: Creates a new spectrum from an existing 2-d spectrum. The initial contents of the new spectrum (named newName) are created by summing channels either vertically or horizontally from the existing spectrum named oldName.
direction determines the axis onto which the projection is performed. If x y channels are summed to produce a single channel. If y, X channels are summed to produce a single channel.

If snapshot, a flag, is zero, once newName is created it is hooked into the histogramming system so that new events can increment that spectrum. If non-zero, this is not done, creating a snapshot projection that never updates.

If contour is provided it must be the name of a contour gate that, if snapshot is 0 will be applied to the newName spectrum. Furthermore, only the channels in oldName that are inside that contour are used to populate the initial values of newName.

The spectrum is entered into SpecTcl spectrum name dictionary, regardless and can, therefore be used wherever a spetrum name can be used both in this API and in SpecTcl's commands. Note that initially, the spectrum is not bound into the display memory but that can be accomplished via sbindSpectra if desired or locally via the sbind command.
Returns information about spectrum definitions for spectra with names that match pattern. If the optional pattern parameter is not supplied it defaults to * which matches all spectrum names.
The returned value is a list of dicts. Each dict describes one spectrum and contains the following keys:
Spectrum name
Spectrum type code. See the SpecTcl command reference spectrum for legal spectrum types.
List of parameter names the spectrum needs. The spectrum type tells how to interpret these.
A list of one or two axis definitions. Each axis definition is a dict with the keys low, high and bins with obvious meanings.
Channel data type this is currently one of long. word or byte.
Name of the gate applied to the spectrum.
Deletes a spectrum named name.

Creates a new spectrum name with the type type. The spectrum uses parameters in a manner that is type dependent. The axes parameter is a list of one (1-d) or 2 (2-d) axis definitions. Each axis is a three element low, high, bins list.
options is a dict (that can be empty). which provides additional spectrum options and the ability of some spectra to be unusual.
The keys the method uses are:
Channel type. One of long, short or byte.
Only used if the type is 2dproj, this specifies the direction of the projection.
Only used for 2dproj, This is the gate that specifies the region projected.

refsect2.title: Parameter access.
refsect2.para: SpecTcl has two levels of parameter definition. Raw parameters make a correspondence between a slot in the CEvent object that the event processing pipeline fills in and a parameter name. This is the oldest and most primitive type of SpecTcl parameter.

The second level of parameter definition was originally developed by Daniel Bazin and provides additional metadata about the tree parameter that can be used to suggest how to build spectra using those parameters. Furthermore, treeparameter creation automatically creates an underlying primitive parameter allocatin an unused slot. Finally the CTreeParameter and CTreeParameterArray classes available to event processors allows event processors to be written without referencing specific slots in the CEvent object.
This set of client methods provide support for manipulating both tree parameters and low level primitive parameters.

listitem.para: Creates a new tree parameter bound to the primitive parameter name. The parameter is assumed to run between low and high (double precision floating point parameters) and has sufficient resolution to allow for a histogram axis to have bins bins. The optional units parameter provides units of measure.

Use cases for creating tree parameters at script level include wanting to wrap an existing primitive parameter (used in the event processors as a primitive parameter) in the metadata that tree parameters have. Furthermore, a treeparameter may be created at script level to allow it to be computed at script level as a psuedo parameter.

Returns a list of dicts that describe the tree parameters with names that match the pattern. pattern can include glob wild card characters and is optional. If not supplied, it defaults to * which matches all tree parameters.
The dicts in the list contain the following keys:
The parameter name.
Suggested axis binning
Suggested axis low limit.
Suggested axis high limit.
Units of measure. THis will be an empty string if none have been specified for the tree parameter.

Returns a list of the tree parameter names that have been programmtically created. Note this includes those created by the treeparameterCreate method or other client software, as well as those created locally via SpecTcl's treeparameter-create
Sets new values for all of the metadata associated with the tree parameter name. See treeparameterCreate for a description of the parameters.
Note that this only affects the metadata associated with the tree parameter. Spectra using the parameter are no modified in any way.
Provides a new channel width for the tree parameter name. This recomputes the bins metadata given the width, low and high limits in the existing metadata so that each bin has the width newInc
Note again, this only affects the metadata in the tree parameter. No spectra that depend on the tree parameter are modified.

See treeparameterSeteBins below for a more direct way to change the binning, though sometimes you really want control over the channel width...e.g. if the units are cm you might want sufficient bins so that each channel is 1mm wide.
Sets the number of recommended bins for the tree parameter name to be newBins.
Sets the treeparameter name units of measure to newUnits
Sets new low (newLow) and new high (newHigh) limits for the metadata associated with name
Tree parameters know if their definitions have been modified. This method checks name and returns a boolean true value if name's was modified

The use case for this method is to reduce the information a program has to write to a saved settings file. Since in general, tree parameters are created programmatically in the C++ code, the only tree parameters that need to be written are those with the change flag set and those created at script level.
Clears the flag that's returned by treeparameterCheck. A suitable smart user interface could do this if, e.g. the tree parameter's metadata, having been modified, is reset to its original condition.

Returns the version string for the tree parameters subsystem. The intent of this is to allow the tree parameter system to have additional capabilities with time. Knowing the version at which a capability was added would allow the application developer to use this interface to determine if specific capabilities are available.
Creates a new primitive parameter; name bound to slot number in the CEvent object filled out by the data analysis pipeline.
metadata is a dict that's used to pass a varying set of optional metadata about the parameter. It can be an empty dict, in which case, the parameter has no metadata
Keys used by this method are:
Optional number of bits of resolution the parameter covers. This provides a range of parameters most suited for a value that comes from some device like a digitizer.
Low limit value of the parameter. Requires high and units also be present.
High limit on the parameter. Requires that low and units also be present.
Units of measure string. No other keys are required. Note that units of measure can be an empty string if needed.
Deletes the primitive parameter name. If the name is an empty string the id parameter is then required and specifies the number of the parameter to delete.
Creates a list of the definitions whose parameter names match the pattern. If pattern is not supplied it defaults to * matching all parameters.
If patternis an empty string id is required and is the parameter number of the parameter to list.
The result is a list of dicts that contain the following keys. Note that metadata that has not been specified will be returned as empty strings.
The parameter name
Th parameter number (id).
Parameter resolution in bits if supplied.
Parameter value limits if supplied.
Parameter units of measure, if supplied.

refsect2.title: Tree variable methods
refsect2.para: Parallel to the treeparameter subsystem is a treevariable subsystem. These are jackets for Tcl variables in SpecTcl that contain floating point values and are both easy to access from C++ code via the CTreeVariable and have additional metadata.
This section of the manpage describes the methods that manipulate tree variables over the REST interface.

listitem.para: Lists all tree variables and their metadata. This returns a list of dicts. Each dict describes a tree variable and contains the following keys:
Name of the tree variable.
Current tree variable value.
Units of measure metadata that's associated with the tree variable.
Modifies a tree variable and its metadata. name specifies the treevariable to modify while value is the new value assigned to that variable and units a new units of measure metadata.
Check the changed flag of the tree variable name. This flag is set automatically if a tree variable value/metadata are modified. In addition, treevariableSetChanged can set this flag.
As with the check flag for tree parameters, the intent is to allow user interface authors to reduce the amount of data written to saved settings file.
Sets the tree variable changed flag for name

Tcl supports tracing variable chagnes. If a variable is modified at script level, traces automatically fire, if, however variables bound to memory are modified by modifying that memory, traces need to be manually fired.
This is needed if a CTreevariable instance if assigned a value by C++ code.

This method programmatically fires any needed variable traces for tree variables that match the optional pattern argument. If pattern is not provided, it default to * which matches all tree variables.

refsect2.title: Filter manipulation methods
refsect2.para: Filter are SpecTcl entities that live on the histogramming pipeline. They can write a subset of events with a subset of parameters to output files. Usually filter files are written such that reading data from filter files is much faster than reading data from event files with a similar number of events.

listitem.para: Creates a new filter object. name is the name that's associated with that object. gate specifies the filter's gate. Only events that satisfy that gate will be written to the filter output file. Note that you can use a T gate to write all events.
parameters specifies the list of parameter names that determines which parameters are written to the output file for each event that satisfies the filter's gate.
Deletes the filter object name.
Enables the filter name to write data. Note that the filter must first be given an output file.
Disables the filter name.
Changes the gate that determines which events are written from filter name to gate.
Sets the file for filter name to path. This determines where the filter, when enabled, will write data.
Returns a list of dicts describing filters whose names match pattern. If the optional pattern command is not provided it defaults to * which matches all filter names.
Each dict in the list describes a filter and contains the following keys:
The name of the filter described by this dict.
The gate that filters events for this filter.
The output file to which this filter writes data. This is an empty string if not yet set.
List of parameter nams of the parameters that will be written to the filter file for each event that satisfies the filter's gate.
Format of the filter file. SpecTcl comes with a built-in format xdr but this can be extended programmatically in the specific tailored SpecTcl that's being run.
Sets the filter format for name to be format.

refsect2.title: Gate manipulation methods
refsect2.para: One of SpecTcl's strengths is its ability to conditionalize the increment of spectra on events that satisfy a condition. SpecTcl refers to these conditions as gates. Gates are applied to spectra to perform this conditionalization.
SpecTcl provides a rich set of gates that will not all be described here. See the SpecTcl command reference. This section describes the methods that can create and manipulate gates.

listitem.para: Produces a list that contains descriptions of the gates whose names match the pattern. If pattern is not provided, it defaults to * which matches all names.
The contents of the list are dicts. Some dict keys are always present while the presence of others depends on the gate type.
Name of the gate.
The SpecTcl gate type code. See the SpecTcl Command Reference discussion of the gate command.
List of gates the gate depends on. Note that for a - gate there will only ever be a single dependent gate.
List of the parameters the gate depends on.
A list of points that define a 2d gate. The points are a list of 2 element sublists where the first element of each sublist is an x coordinate and the second the y.
Low and High limits of 1-d gates.
Mask value for the mask gates.

Deletes the gate name. Note that SpecTcl never actually deletes gates as that produces ill defined results for gate dependencies. Instead deleted gates are turned into False gates (type F). This has well defined effects on gate dependencies.
Creates a simple 1-d gate. The gate will be called name and has a type gatetype. parameters is a list of the parameter names the gate depends on. low and high are the limits of the gate.
THe only valid gate types are s and gs.

Creates a simple 2d gate name. The gate type is gatetype and must be one of b,c,gb,gc. xparameters and yparameters specify the list of parameter names on the X and Y axis of the gate. Note that for gamma 2-d gates, it does not matter which parameters are in which list and, in fact, all parameters could just be in one of the two lists.
The coordinates of the gate figure are corresponding elements of the xcoords and ycoords parameters. For example, the first point is ([lindex $xcoords 0], [lindex $ycoords 0]). etc.
Creates a mask gate name. The gate type (gatetype), must be one of am, em, nm. The gate is checked on the parameter parameter using the mask mask.
Creates a compound gate. These are gates that depend on other gates. name will be the name of the new gate which will have the gate type gatetype. The gatetype msut be one of +,*,c2band,-.

gates is a list of the names of the gate this gate depends on. c2band gate must only have two dependent gates and they must be type b. Similarly - gates must only have one gate although it can be of any type.

refsect2.title: Dynamic Pipeline Management
refsect2.para: Prior to SpecTcl 5.0, the data anlaysis pipeline that transforms raw data into unpacked parameters was defined at the C++ level and there was little native support for dynamically modifying the pipeline.
In SpecTcl 5.0, the pman command allows users to compose pipelines from event processors that have been registered and to select which of the pipelines is active at any given time.
This section describes methods that provide client access to this capability through the SpecTcl REST server.

listitem.para: Creates a new empty analysis pipeline.
Lists the names of the pipelines that have been defined and match the optional pattern. If pattern is not supplied, then it defaults to * matching all names.
Returns a dict that describes the current pipeline. Keys are name, the pipeline name, and processors, the oredered list of event processors in the pipeline.
Returns information about piplines with names that match the pattern. This defaults to * if not provided.
The return value is a list of dicts. Each dict describes a pipeline who's name matches the pattern. Each dict has the same format as the dict returned from pmanCurrent

Returns a list names of the registered event processors. Registered event processors are the processors that can be strung together in event processing pipelines. If pattern is provided only the event processors with names matching pattern (with glob wild-card characters) are listed. If not supplied pattern defaults to * which matches all processor names.

Tells SpecTcl to use the named pipeline as the current event processing pipeline. Starting with the next event received, SpecTcl will use the name pipeline to extract parameters from the raw event data.
Adds processor, an event processor registered with the pipeline manager to the end of the event processing pipeline named pipeline.
Removes the event processor named processor from the event processing pipeline named pipeline.
Removes all event processors fromt he processing pipeline named pipeline

Creates a new processing pipeline named new that is a copy of the pipeline named source. Once created, the processors in the two pipelines can diverge by using the pipeline editing facilities either documented above or in direct SpecTcl command execution.

refsect2.title: Event Built Data
refsect2.para: Increasingly complex experiments are built out of quasi-independent detector subsystems that are coordinated by a common time base. The NSCLDAQ event builder assembles events that are coincident within some time window and ships them downstream in the experiment's data flow.

This set of functions supports building an event processor that associates an event processing pipeline (see previous section) with data from each expected source in the built events. This allows the initial raw event unpacking stage of event processing to be built from the standard software that is used by the developers/maintainers of each detector subsystem.

listitem.para: Creates a new event processnar name that can be configured to analyze event built data. The new event processor will automatically build several diagnostic parameters whose base names will be basename. These diagnistic parameter support the creation of typical event builder diagnostic spectra that can be used to monitor the synchronization of the various data sources.

One of the diagnostic parameters is the timestamp calibrated to double precision floating point seconds. This supports diagnostic spectra that show time evolution (e.g. the time difference between fragments from data source pairs as it evolves int time should be unchanging).

Associates an event processing pipeline pipe (see the previous subsection) with an event source id source in an event builder event processor name. If the event processor is given an event built event to analyze, the pipeline will be activated to analyze data from that source id if it is encounted in that event.

The idea is that several calls to this method build up an event processor capable of analyzing data from all expected data sources using the event processing pipline that is normally used for each event source were it run by itself.
Lists the event processor names that have been created. Only names that match the optional pattern argument are listed. If pattern is not supplied, it defaults to *.

refsect2.title: Tracing
refsect2.para: SpecTcl supports establishing traces on changes tot he parameter, gate and spectrum dictionaries. Traces for a REST client/server environment are problematic because the REST protocol does not have a mechanism for the server to request an action by the on its own.
The methods below allow the server to buffer traces on behalf of an interested client which can the fetch accumulated traces.

listitem.para: Establishes client interest in traces. The retention parameter specifies the minimum amount of time trace information will be retained for this client in seconds. If traces are fetched periodically, this should be some small multiple of the time between fetches.
The return value from this method is an integer token value that represents this client in the server's trace buffering subsystem. It should be used in calls to traceDone and traceFetch
This method indicates the client no longer needs the server to buffer traces on its behalf. The token parameter to this method should be the token returned from traceEstablish.
Once successfully completed, the token is no longer valid.

Fetches the traces buffered since the last call to traceFetch. The traces are returned as a dict with three attributes. The contents of each attributs are a list in which each list element describes a trace.

The parameter attribute contains the parameter traces. The first element of each list is the text add or delete indicating the what happened. THe second element is the name of the parameter that was either added or deleted.

The gate attribute contains the gate traces. The first element of each list is the text add, delete or changed indicating why the trace fired. The second element of the list is the name of the affected gate.

The spectrum attribute contains spectrum traces. The first element of each list is the text add or delete indicating the operation that fired the trace. The second element of each list is the name of the parameter that was affected.

Finally the bindings attribute provides sbind and unbind trace information. The first element of each list is the type of trace add or remove The second element the name of the affected spectrum and the last, the binding id (spectrum slot) affected/allocated.

refsect2.title: Miscelaneous Methods
refsect2.para: The methods described in this section don't fit into any nice categories.

listitem.para: Performs an integration in a spectrum, name, within some region of interest, roi.

The Region of Interest roi can have several forms. It can be the name of a gate within which the integration will take place, or, if the spectrum is one dimensional, a pair of numbers that are the low and high limits of integration or, if the spectrum is two dimensional, a list of x/y pairs that describe contour.
Regions of interest that are not gates must be expressed in parameter coordinates, not spectrum channels and the integration takes place in that coordinate system.

The integration returns a dict. The centriod key provides the centroid of the integration as either a single value or a list of two values, depending on spectrum dimensionality. The fwhm key provides the full width at half maximum under the assumption the integration is over a gaussian shaped peak. It too is either a single value or two values, depending on spectrum dimensionality. The counts key provides the number of counts in the region of integration.

Creates a puedo parameter. name is the name of an as yet unused parameter. parameters are the names of the parameters needed to compute the pseudo and body is the script body used to compute the parameter. For more information, see the SpecTcl command reference guide for the pseudo command.
Returns a list of descriptions of pseudo parameters whose names match pattern. If pattern is not supplied, it defaults to * which matches everything.

The result is a list of dicts with the keys: name containing the name of the pseudo parameter, parameters containing a list of the parameter names needed to compute the pseudo and body, the script body needed to compute the pseudo value for each event.
Deletes the computation that produces the value for the pseudo parameter name. The parameter is still defind and a new pseudoCreate method call can specify it.

Reads one spectrum from the file filename. What is done with that spectrum depeds on the (potentially empty) dict options. Note that in SpecTcl normally a file descriptor can be used as the source of the file, this cannot be acommplished in the client. See, however, command.
THe options dict can have the following keys; all of which have reasonable defaults:
Format of the data file. Defaults to ascii. The set of formats is extensible, however the built in formats are ascii and binary.

Boolean that, if 1, (the default) does not attempt to hook the histogram read in to the histogrammer but, instead, creates a snapshot (frozen) spectrum. If 0, the spectrum will, if possible, be hooked to the histogrammer and increment as additional data are processed.
If nonzero, and a spectrum with the name specified in the file exists, the existing spectrum is replaced. If zero, the default, a new spectrum name will be derived.
If nonzero (the default), the spectrum will be bound into display memory. If zero, it will not (it can be later bound of course).

Write the spectra named in spectra to file named by filename. The format parameter specifies the file format and defaults to ascii if not supplied. SpecTcl has two built in spectrum file formats; ascii, which is most commonly used and binary, which hardly anyone uses. Additionally the SpecTcl file format can be extended at the C++ level.
Returns the key of the SYSV shared memory region that SpecTcl is using for display memory.
Returns the number of DisplayMegabytes used by SpecTcl for its shared memory region.
Returns the SpecTcl version as a dict containing the keys major, minor and editlevel
Note that this requires the rootinterface package be pulled into SpecTcl. Creates a new Root tree that gets populated by successive data and written to file.
Root Trees are similar to SpecTcl Filters but have the format of CERN Root trees and are aware of changes in run state.

name is the name of the root tree. parameterPatterns specifies a set of patterns that determine the parameters that are written to the tree. Finally, if supplied, gate specifies the name of a gate. Only events that pass the gate get added to the file.
Note that the parameterPatterns is applied statically. That is if subsequently a new parameter is created that matches one of the patterns, it is not added to the tree.
Deletes the root tree name.
Lists the properties of trees who's name matches pattern. If that pattern is not provided, it defaults to * matching all trees.
The returned value is a list of dicts. Each dict describes a tree using the keys tree - the name of the tree, parameters the list of parameter patterns and gate the gate (could be an empty string).
Executes an arbitrary command, script in the SpecTcl server. This allows for access to user defined commands and other client needs that have not been foreseen.
Returns the values of some variables maintained by the server. The result is a dict whose keys are the names of those variables and whose values are the values of the variable specified in the key.

Returns a list of dicts containing information about the current SpecTcl display memory mirrors that are being maintained. If the optional pattern parameter is provided this list is filtered to the mirrors that match the pattern as a host name. The pattern can contain glob characters.
Each dict in the list describes one active mirror and contains the following keys:
Name of a host on which a mirror is being maintained.
The SYS-V shared memory key of that mirrror.

refsect1.title: OMISSIONS
refsect1.para: There is no REST access to the rootexec command as the most common use case is to pop up a TBrowser to allow ROOT interaction with the spectrum data and, that could only pop up on any X-11 DISPLAY connection of the SpecTcl server, not the client.

refsynopsisdiv.programlisting:
package require SpecTclRestCommand
SpecTclRestCommand::initialize spectcl-host spectcl-port

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This package, which is in the TclLibs directory tree of the SpecTcl installation beginning with SpecTcl 5.5, provides most of the SpecTcl commands in terms of the SpecTcl REST client interface. The intent is to allow existing SpecTcl Graphical User interfaces to run as REST clients should SpecTcl be run "headless" under the NSCLDAQ manager.
Assuming the GUI makes use of none of the unimplemented features described in DIFFERENCES below, the only requirements are that a framing script be run that

listitem.para: Includes the package via package require as shown in the synopsis (note that this, in turn will require that the SpecTcl TcLLibs directory be included in the package search path).

Initialize access to the REST interface by invoking SpecTclRestCommand::initilialize. This command takes, as parameters, the host on which the SpecTcl providing the REST interface and the port on which that REST interface is listening for connections.

refsect1.para: While not strictly necessary, the REST client used can be destroyed by calling SpecTclRestCommand::shutdown, which takes no command parameters. One use case for this is an application which interacts with more than one SpecTcl REST server through this package. Such an application can invoke SpecTclRestCommand::shutdown followed by SpecTclRestCommand::initialize to switch REST servers.

Note, as is usual for REST clients, no persistent connection is formed with the server. The client forms a connection for each command and closes that connection once the server has returned any information that command returns.

refsect1.title: DIFFERENCES
refsect1.para: The command implemented are not 100% compatible with SpecTcl. This section describes the differences between the native command set and the commands provided by this package.

formalpara.title: Additions
formalpara.para: The need to initialize and the ability to shutdown REST access have been documented in DESCRIPTION above.

refsect1.para: An additional command execCommand passes its single argument as a command string to be executed by the SpecTcl Tcl interpreter. One use case for this is to open a file and obtain its file discriptor for later use with, e.g. sread or swrite. A second use is to form the basis of user written facades to support any commands that have been added to SpecTcl. Finally, it's possible to use this command to reduce the number of requests needed to perform, what otherwise might be, time consuming requests.
execCommand returns any result the requested command might return.

SpectTcl maintains several global variables that user interfaces may depend on. Two commands are provided to maintain the same variables in the client side. The execCommand interface can be used by authors of client software to maintain additional variables.
updateVariables fetches the contents of those variables and updates identically named client side global variables with their values.

maintainVariables requires the services of the event loop. It periodically runs updateVariables. Its single command line parameter is the number of seconds between update requests. Note that the REST server is written so that a single client request updates all variables.
Here is a list of the variables that updateVariables will update:

listitem.para: The number of megabytes of display shared memory requested (normally modified from the defaut in SpecTclInit.tcl)
Array containing some SpecTcl statistics. The indices of this array are:
Number of events accepted by the event processing pipeline (that is the number that returned kfTRUE).
Number of events that were accepted since the most recent begin run.
Online state of the program. I believe this is set nonzero by some scripts that use attach -pipe to attach to the NSCLDAQ data connector.
Number of events batched up by the event processing pipline for processing by the analysis (histogramming) pipeline.
Initial size of the CEvent 'arrays' when they are created. Note they expand as needed and are recycled so this parameter is less critical than it used to be.
The top level directory of the SpecTcl installation the server was built against.

For NSCLDAQ-8 and earlier data this is the sequence number of the most recent buffer of data seen. For NSCLDAQ-10 and later this is filled in from trigger statistics ring items to be the number of event triggered ring items that were produced as of the last trigger statistics ring item. This is used by some GUIs to compute the approximate fraction of data SpecTcl has analyzed.

For data acquisition systems that have a run number that can be extracted from their data, this is the run number of the data source most recently opened. Note that if SpecTcl is attached to an online data source this may not update until the beginning of the next run.
This is the state of any current run that's being analyzed. It's most useful when analyzing online data. It can take the values: Active, Halted, and Paused.
Type of displayer used by SpecTcl. This is taken from the SpecTclInit.tcl file unless the default xamine is not overidden.

For NSCLDAQ 8 and earlier this is the number of buffers SpecTcl has analyzed. For NSCLDAQ11, this is the number of physics event ring items that have been analyzed. Ths, in conjunction with LastSequence are used by GUIs to compute the fraction of the data SpecTcl has analyzed in the online environment. Note that there are no longer any online NSCLDAQ-8 systems.
For data from DAQ systems with titles associated with their runs, this is the title of the most recently attached data source.

formalpara.title: Omissions
formalpara.para: There are command features that have not been fully implemented. In most cases these are not heavily used commands or features. If one or more of these causes problems, please report your needs.

listitem.para: The rootexec is not supported because normally this is used to access the graphical user interface of Root (e.g. pop up a TBrowser), and REST server SpecTcl's may not have access to a display.
Note that the execommand can be used if you need to run a macro that does not require Root's graphics.
gate -list's -byid option is not implemented.
gate ?-new?, gate creation, does support the creation of T or F gates.
parameter -list -byid is not supported.
parameter -delete -id is not supported.
spectrum -list does not implement the -byid and the -id options.
spectrum -delete does not implement the -id option.
unbind does not implement passing a list of Xamine mapping ids (xids) to be unbound.

refsect2.title: Tracing implementation
refsect2.para: The SpecTcl command set provides scripts with the ability to establish and remove traces which invoke scripts when significant events occur in the parameter, spectrum and gate dictionaries. This section provide implementation note on the implementation of traces in this package.

The idea of traces is not well supported by REST. Specifically, the expectation of REST is that the client drives all interaction between client and server via explicit HTTP requests. A direct implementation of traces, on the other hand, would require the server to make requests for action on the part of the client for every trace that fired.

That leaves implementation of traces to polling on the client's behalf. Automated polling requires an event loop to dispatch the poll procedure. In practice, this is is not a restriction as the primary use case of this package and tracing is to maintain a GUI that, in the past, ran directly within SpecTcl itself and Tk scripts, by their nature run the event loop.
There are two choices about how to implement trace polling:

listitem.para: Poll the contents of all of the traced dictionaries, compute differencese and dispatch changes based on those differences.
Provide mechsnisms in the server to buffer traces themselves and poll the actual traces.

refsect2.para: As there ae SpecTcl cases with thousands of parameters and spectra, the first alternative can be expensive. Therefore SpecTcl's REST server provides the second alternative.

On the first attempt to interact with traces, the SpecTclRestCommand package expresses interest in traces to the server, which, begins server side trace buffering. It also initiates periodic trace polling. The trace poll proc dispatches appropriate traces to any established trace scripts in a manner that is compatible with what SpecTcl itself provided.
This implies that:

listitem.para: Scripts making use of tracing must enter the event loop in a manner that allows the trace polling proc to execute periodically, or at least significantly more often than the value of ::SpecTclRestCommand::tracePollInterval*100 at the time the first tracing operation was done by the script.

There is a latency between the event that actually would fire the trace and the trace being fired in the client script. This latency is determined by the periodicity of the polling proc which, by default is executed 2 seconds. The number of seconds between polls is determined by the variable ::SpecTclRestCommand::tracePollInterval.

Scripts can set this variable but, since its value also determines the server side trace retention period (100*::SpecTclRestCommand::tracePollInterval) at the time the first trace operation is performed by the client script), it's recommended to set this value early, during script initialization.

If a script exits without executing SpecTclRestCommand::shutdown, the server will continue to buffer traces for the script. Note that normally this is not an awful problem as the retention period will prevent the trace buffer from growing without bounds and at some point, SpecTcl's parameter, spectrum and gate dictionaries converge to a final, static state.
